table.name: Gothic Horror; Grand Cathedral District
rows: A banshee's wail echoes through the cavernous nave, preceding a tragic death.
The beast-repelling incense becomes tainted, allowing monsters to infiltrate the cathedral under the cover of night.
Screams are heard from the abandoned asylum below, along with rattling chains and strange machinery.
A deceased loved one's voice pleads from beyond the grave to meet them in the chamber atop the Pillar of Blood.
The enormous bell towers are suddenly overrun by ravens cawing ominously as they circle overhead.

table.name: Gothic Horror; New Bridge District
rows: Heavy rainfall causes bodies to float up in the canals from the remains of a previous Hunt. Some seem not entirely dead...
Strange skittering and screeches are heard from within boarded up buildings.
Severed body parts are found arranged ritualistically near the lightning rods of the Scion's fortress.
Ghostly figures are glimpsed wandering the ruins of buildings destroyed in the First War.
The generators in the Scion's fortress suddenly shutdown, plunging the district into darkness.

table.name: Gothic Horror; Outside the Walls
rows: Strange rituals are glimpsed at night in the ruins of the cosmic seminary.
Half-eaten corpses are found hanging from trees by their guts in the forest surrounding the city.
Glowing eyes are seen peering from the gloom in the acidic ruins of Jgerweiler.
Mournful sobbing is heard from fresh grave sites in the Cemetery of Ash.
Dark riders are seen passing on trails leading to the forest of the Circle of Symbiosis.

table.name: Gothic Horror; Paterna Iter District
rows: Fresh blood drips down the vines of the sealed black parish church.
Strange chanting is heard from the ruins late at night, along with flickering torchlight.
Partially eaten corpses missing various organs are found across many homes.
Plants in the vertical farms become animated and lash out at workers tending to them.
Guests at a garden party turn on each other in a frenzy, as if possessed by an evil spirit.

table.name: Gothic Horror; Ruby District
rows: Beastly howls and snarls echo from the depths of the sewers at night.
A mansion long thought abandoned is lit up and music is heard, but it goes silent when investigated.
Strange worms adorning human faces are discovered burrowing into corpses in the communal cemeteries.
Severed body parts are arranged in a grotesque sculpture in the town square.
A little girl's creepy singing voice foretells victims before they are slain by beasts.

table.name: Gothic Horror; Sanctified District
rows: Wax replicas of nobles are found staring from windows, preceding their disappearance.
Mysterious scratching and movement is heard from portraits on the walls.
Guests at a masquerade ball are slowly poisoned, leading to bloody coughing fits.
Unearthly screams are heard from the catacombs beneath the castles.
Plants in the gardens wither and die overnight, replaced with disturbing bone sculptures.

table.name: Gothic Horror; Shrouded District
rows: A miner goes mad, convinced the lumps of coal he digs up are fossilized hearts of the dead.
Mysterious symbols and runes are found painted in blood throughout an abandoned warehouse.
Echoing cries are heard from a mine shaft that collapsed years ago, killing all workers inside.
The smog takes on a sinister face and whispers dark secrets to lone wanderers.
A masked plague doctor stalks victims under the cover of the smog, though their murders resemble anything but medical research.

table.name: Gothic Horror; Waterfront District
rows: Bloated corpses wash up on the shores missing their faces.
The Tidewatcher lighthouse stops rotating at night and blood begins to seep from it.
Sinister shadows flit beneath the surface of the water under the bridges.
Ghostly visages are seen pleading from barred windows at the Abyssal Keep.
A ship is found drifting, its entire crew slaughtered and crucified to the mast.

table.name: Guardian Domain Spells
rows: {@spell protection from evil and good|PHB}, {@spell sanctuary|PHB}
{@spell guardian of faith|PHB}, {@spell Otiluke's Resilient Sphere|PHB|resilient sphere}

table.name: Indefinite Madness
rows: You become heavily reliant on substances to cope with the meaninglessness of this painful existence.

If you have a bad habit, such as drinking or drugs, it takes over and you become addicted. If you have no such habit, you develop alcoholism. You take a −3 penalty to all attack rolls, saving throws, and ability checks, but if you are under the effect of the substance, you also gain a +3 bonus to saving throws against the {@condition frightened} condition or further madness.

You begin to heavily medicate yourself to numb the pain of life. You develop one of the following vices most in line with your personality: promiscuity, drug abuse, alcoholism, or smoking. If you do not partake in your vice at least twice every 24 hours, you suffer from a {@dice -1d6} penalty to Wisdom saving throws until you do so.
Drugs, alcohol, and other vices stop having any effect on you. You immediately expel any vices consumed before you can metabolize them and are repulsed by all carnal thoughts.
Life is bad and is only getting worse.
Whenever you fail an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw, you have disadvantage on your next ability check, attack roll, or saving throw.

You feel the world is rotting and become reluctant to try anything new, only relying on what you know has worked in the past. You categorically refuse to try anything new that you haven't experienced before gaining this madness, such as a new spell, feature, or tavern.

In the past, you may have been a promising individual, but those days are long gone. You are no longer proficient in any skills and instead suffer a penalty equal to your proficiency bonus to any skills in which you were proficient. If an ability allows you to gain a bonus to a check (such as {@classFeature Expertise|Bard|PHB|3|PHB} or {@classFeature Jack of All Trades|Bard|PHB|2|PHB}), you can no longer do so.
You develop a hatred of your own body.

When you first develop this madness, it doesn't manifest itself until you are alone for 10 seconds or more with a blade. You self amputate a limb in anger and destroy the removed {@homebrew appendage|appendice} of flesh.

You begin to wear mountains of clothing that hide as much of your body as possible and refuse to show even an inch of skin to anyone. If you realize that your skin has become exposed, you have disadvantage on all checks and attack rolls until you hide it again.

Perhaps it would be better if your soul left this wretched body. When you are reduced to 0 hit points, you gain two failed death saving throws, and you automatically fail any further death saving throws.
You lose the ability to manage your stress properly.

Whenever you are exposed to a stressful situation, you burst into a frenzy, attacking the origin of your stress recklessly until it dies or you are knocked {@condition unconscious}. The GM determines when you are in a stressful situation.
You automatically fail saving throws against the {@condition frightened} condition and can't benefit from effects that would otherwise make you immune to {@condition fear|SGttEH}.
Whenever you are exposed to a stressful or social situation, you retreat within yourself. You have disadvantage on all Charisma and Dexterity checks and lose any boastfulness your character may have.
Your eyes begin to blister as the Eldritch Truth reveals itself to you.
You become {@condition blinded|PHB|blind} and cannot regain sight while afflicted by this madness.
You gain the ability to see into the Ethereal Plane but lose the ability to see the Material Plane. You are {@condition blinded} to creatures and objects on the Material Plane.
Your eyes grow dark and you despise the light. While in sunlight or bright moonlight, you have disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on {@skill Perception} checks that rely on sight.
The madness ignites your nervous system, and your mind begins to beckon the pain.

Your subconscious screams at you, urging you to suffer the pain. You have disadvantage on saving throws against effects that deal damage to you, and attack rolls against you have advantage. In exchange, you have advantage on saving throws against non-damaging effects, as your mind sees them as beneath you.

Whenever you take more than 20 points of damage in a turn, your body detonates psychically. You and all creatures within 30 feet of you must succeed on an Intelligence saving throw or take {@damage 3d10} psychic damage. You have disadvantage on this saving throw.

You become fascinated with the afterlife. Whenever a creature within your sight is {@condition unconscious} and at 0 hit points, you feel the urge to finish them off, and must use your turn to try to kill them.
Mysterious powers from beyond grasp you, and you attempt to cope in various ways.

You become obsessed with one object in your possession. If that item isn't precisely right all the time, it gnaws away at your peace of mind. While that item is not right, you have disadvantage on all ability checks and attack rolls.

Initially, nothing happens. [Only the GM can know the following] The next time you fall {@condition unconscious} in battle, you develop a severe trauma around it. If you encounter that enemy in battle again while under the effect of this madness, you become cursed. While cursed in this way, when you finish a long rest, you must make a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, your mind wrestles with your past failures, and you do not gain the benefits of the long rest.
You develop a strange phobia. It could be fear of long words, the dark, or another aspect of your life. Talk with your GM to decide which one would suit your character.
Your heart begins to falter; such a reality cannot possibly exist.

You lose contact with reality. You start seeing people that don't exist and hearing sounds that aren't there. This effect also applies in battle, where you see enemies that aren't on the battlefield. Make a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw at the start of each of your turns. On a failed save, you must use your action to attack one target of the GM's choice.
You become a compulsive liar. You must make a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw each time you attempt to tell the truth. On a failure, you lie, even when it's against your best interest.

You become obsessed with stealing small, valuable items. When you notice these items, you must make a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw to resist the urge to steal. On a failure, you attempt to steal something nearby, regardless of the consequences.
You begin to lose control of your nerves and mind.

Your senses become painfully heightened, causing discomfort and confusion. Unable to gain mental clarity amidst the cacophony of your senses, you have disadvantage on any ability checks that rely on sight, hearing, smell, taste, or touch, and disadvantage on Wisdom saving throws.
You randomly teleport a short distance (10 to 60 feet) at inopportune moments. The GM determines the timing and destination of these teleportations.
You broadcast your thoughts telepathically to creatures within a 60-foot radius, losing the ability to keep secrets or to surprise any creature within range.
Your body mutates in maladaptive ways.

You become extremely sensitive to a specific element (fire, cold, lightning, acid, poison, or thunder), feeling intense pain even from minor exposure. You become vulnerable to that damage type. This effect removes any resistance or immunity you might have to that damage type.

You become a walking lightning rod. Any lightning or effects that deal lightning damage within 120 feet of you also bend in your direction, striking you as well. Further, you automatically fail saving throws against effects that deal lightning damage.

You lose all the hair on your body, leading to thermoregulation problems. Manikins are immune to this effect. You have disadvantage on saving throws against {@hazard extreme cold|DMG} and {@hazard extreme heat|DMG|heat}. Further, you have disadvantage on saving throws against diseases and poison, and you lose any resistance to poison damage.
Your body perceives reality in abnormal ways.

Your body phases in and out of reality, causing it to partially pass through objects and creatures. When you make an attack or cast a spell, there is a {@chance 50|50% chance|Madness|The attack fails.|The attack suceeds.} it phases into the Ethereal Plane and passes harmlessly through your targets.

You perceive distances inaccurately, with objects appearing closer or farther away than they actually are. You have disadvantage on ranged attack rolls and {@skill Perception} checks that rely on sight.

You experience time at an inconsistent pace, with moments seeming to stretch or compress unpredictably. You have disadvantage on initiative rolls and must roll a {@dice d6} at the start of each of your turns to determine which actions you can take (1–2: one action, bonus action, or movement; 3–4: one movement, and either one action or one bonus action; 5–6: no change).
Your mind begins to play tricks on you, feeding you delusions.

You become overly confident and take unnecessary risks. You must make a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw before attempting any cautious or well-thought-out action. On a failure, you act impulsively instead.
You believe you are a deity, royalty, or another powerful figure, and have disadvantage on all Wisdom and Charisma checks when interacting with others.

You believe you are of another race. You can only speak in that race's native language, and if that language isn't Common, you lose the ability to speak Common. If you don't already know that race's language, you instead produce sounds that seem close to the language, but are in reality complete gibberish.
You develop antisocial personality traits, becoming the embodiment of chaos and madness.

Whenever you roll initiative, you begin to dance. At the start of each of your turns, you must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw to stop dancing for that turn. On a failure, you continue to dance, as per the {@spell Otto's Irresistible Dance|PHB|irresistible dance} spell.

You are overcome with fits of uncontrollable laughter at inappropriate times, making it difficult to communicate or concentrate. If you are {@status concentration|PHB|concentrating} on a spell, you must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw at the start of each of your turns or lose {@status concentration}. Further, you have disadvantage on {@skill Stealth} checks.
You become ravenous and must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or be compelled to consume any food, including unappetizing, rancid, or downright abhorrent sustenance you come across.
You become plagued by a transcendent hatred.
You develop an alternate personality that attempts to destroy everything you care for and nurture anything you despise.

You develop an irrational hatred for a specific creature, object, or situation of the GM's choice. You must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw when you encounter the hated subject or become hostile toward it for 1 hour, or until the target is removed from your sight or is destroyed.

You gleam at the idea of betrayal. Whenever multiple creatures are within range of an attack you are about to make, roll a {@dice d20}. On a10 or lower, you randomly target another creature instead of your original target.
Your body starts acting in strange ways.
Your Strength and Dexterity scores become reversed.
You become convinced that you're suffering from a grave illness, which may or may not be real, and have disadvantage on Constitution saving throws and checks.
Your creature type becomes undead. Manikins lose any shred of humanity they had and become constructs. Magical healing has no effect on you.

You become plagued by nightmares, leaving you perpetually exhausted. If you have fewer than 2 levels of {@condition exhaustion} when you finish a long rest, you rouse with 2 levels of {@condition exhaustion}.

You gain an intense fear of a certain creature type (GM's choice). If you are within 10 feet of that creature type, you must use your movement and action to {@action Dash} away from them on your turn. In addition, creatures of that type have advantage on {@action opportunity attack|PHB|opportunity attacks} against you.
The horrors you've seen tie your tongue and throat. You lose the ability to speak and make sounds, including the vocal components of spells.

The moon, and all its eldritch forms, beckon you. You have disadvantage on any saving throw caused by lunar effects (direct or indirect), and you have advantage on all ability checks regarding knowledge of the moon.

Your Eldritch Ascension fails. Your speed is reduced by half, and you lose the ability to teleport. If you are teleported against your will, such as with a {@spell banishment} spell, you take {@damage 3d10} force damage as the cosmos takes its pound from your flesh as punishment.

Your Eldritch Ascension partially succeeds. Your creature type changes to aberration. You gain resistance to psychic damage, have advantage on saving throws against telepathy, but lose all empathy, conferring disadvantage on {@skill Insight} and {@skill Persuasion} checks. In addition, you understand {@language Deep Speech}, and you have disadvantage on saving throws against {@condition charmed|PHB|charm} effects from aberrations.
The beast within you awakens and takes control.

The beast begins to gnaw at your mind, forcing you to stay alert to ward it. Whenever you fall {@condition unconscious}, roll {@dice 1d2}. On a 1, your mind loses control and the next time you awaken, the beast within you holds control over your body. Until you next fall {@condition unconscious}, you are under the GM's control as the chaotic evil beast within you seeks to join other beasts and banish you from your body. On a 2, you maintain or reclaim your sanity upon rousing.

Your body transforms, yet a trace of your humanity remains. Your race becomes {@race scourgeborne|SGttEH}. Talk with your GM to determine the subrace most appropriate for your character. Nothing short of a {@spell wish} spell can undo this transformation. If you're already a scourgeborne, treat this roll as a 10 and apply the madness effects below instead.
You become a beast or monstrosity of the GM's choice with a CR equal to half your level (rounded up), and you lose your mind. You become a creature under the GM's control.

table.name: Long-Term Madness
rows: The eldritch corruption profoundly weakens your body.
Your frail body is easily pushed around; each time you take damage you are pushed back 10 feet.
You are easily fatigued, and physical effort puts a heavy toll on your body. You require 4 more hours than usual to finish a long rest.
Your legs can barely hold you up; each time you take damage you are knocked {@condition prone}.

Your contact with the beyond awakens powers within you. You learn {@filter one random cantrip from the warlock spell list|spells|source=|level=0|class=warlock}. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.
You become repulsed by this world's magic. Each time you cast or are affected by a spell, you retch and reel, losing your reaction until the start of your next turn.

You cannot handle the newfound magic within you, which sporadically seeps from you when injured. Whenever you take 15 or more points of damage from a single attack, you explode in a discharge of arcane energy. You and each creature within 10 feet of you must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 2d10} force damage. This explosion cannot be triggered again for {@dice 1d6} rounds.

Intense paranoia forces you to be on the alert for anything and anyone, protecting what little is left of you. You gain a {@dice 1d4} bonus to any {@skill Perception} or {@skill Insight} check that you make.
You are sulking and sullen; these negative thoughts in your head cause you to demean yourself during any conversation you have.
Your worthlessness seeps into every aspect of your life, gnawing at whatever remnant of competence you have left. You have a {@dice -1d4} penalty to any ability check you make.
You lose perception of your power.
Not realizing your limits, you push yourself beyond what you are capable of. Whenever you deal damage, add damage equal to one roll of the lowest damage die used.

You don't realize your strength; whenever you have to use your body, you either apply too much force or not enough. Your handshakes can be like a vice grip or dead fish, your hugs suffer the same fate, and any other physical activity you try to perform is a gamble.
Afraid of shattering your body, you involuntarily restrain your power. Whenever you deal damage, subtract damage equal to one roll of the lowest damage die used (minimum 0).
The Eldritch Truth reveals itself to you.
Able to understand this Truth, you gain proficiency in a random Intelligence skill (chosen by the GM) and can add twice your proficiency bonus to any check you make using that skill.

You become fascinated by what lies beyond. Whenever you notice or hear of something of eldritch nature, you drop whatever you are doing to enquire more about it and attempt to get closer to it, physically or otherwise.
The revelations from beyond beckon to you, urging you to learn more, to be more. You have disadvantage on saving throws against madness.
The madness ignites your nervous system, melting it away.
Any pain you would feel completely vanishes. You are immune to being {@condition stunned} and can only fall {@condition unconscious} as a result of reaching 0 hit points.
Your damaged nerves transmit a constant feeling of itchiness. This feeling vanishes when your skin is in direct contact with metal.

You are in constant pain from the nerve damage, which prevents you from focusing or bringing your utmost in battle. You can't add your Dexterity modifier to your Armor Class and have disadvantage on all Dexterity checks and saving throws.
Powers from beyond grasp you and merge with your body.

You manage to bring these otherworldly powers under your control. You have advantage on Constitution saving throws to maintain {@status concentration}. In addition, if you fail a saving throw, you can choose to succeed instead. If you do, you then need to roll on the {@table long-term madness|SGttEH} table again, gaining a new effect.
Attempting to understand what has merged with you, you start experiencing derealization. You are completely alienated from your surroundings at all times and get surprised by any physical contact.

These new powers are too much for you to handle, draining your mind. You have disadvantage on Intelligence checks, Wisdom checks, and Charisma checks, as well as Constitution saving throws to maintain {@status concentration}.
Your heart begins to falter; such a reality cannot possibly exist.
Your elevated heart rate increases your awareness. You gain a +3 bonus to your passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score and your initiative rolls.

The unexpected is too much for you to handle. Whenever you are surprised, you scream at the top of your lungs. If you are surprised in combat, you fall {@condition unconscious} until the start of your next turn.

Your heart weakens, literally. You gain a level of {@condition exhaustion} which cannot be removed until the madness ends. Whenever you become {@condition frightened}, you gain another level of {@condition exhaustion}. Apart from the first, {@condition exhaustion} gained from this madness can be removed as normal.
Your futile attempts at staving off the madness have left your body scarred.
The scar tissue only thickens your skin. You gain a +1 bonus to AC.

The scars that cover your body are beyond repulsive, causing most people to experience fear at their sight, especially children. You have a +2 bonus to {@skill Intimidation} checks and a −2 penalty to {@skill Persuasion} checks.
You suffer severe scarring over an extensive portion of your anatomy. Anytime you take bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage, you suffer an extra {@damage 1d6} damage of that type.
The madness causes your body to rot, unable to withstand the eldritch influence.
Your mind embraces the idea that your body will rot away, and welcomes it; after all, everyone withers away eventually. You have immunity to the {@condition poisoned} condition.
The rot within your body is nauseating. You experience a constant feeling of disgust, and any time you smell something foul, you spend your action heaving.

Vicious wounds of eldritch nature ravage your flesh. Your hit point maximum is reduced by 1 every 24 hours. If your hit point maximum drops to 0, you die. You or another creature can tend to the wounds during a long rest, making a {@dc 16} {@skill Medicine} check once every 24 hours. After five successes, the wounds heals.
The beast within you awakens and takes control.

Most of your humanity remains, yet enough of the beast is unleashed. You gain advantage on Dexterity saving throws. In addition, each of your hands transforms into a claw, which you can use as a weapon if it's empty. It deals {@damage 1d6} slashing damage on a hit. Once on each of your turns when you attack with a claw using the {@action Attack} action, you can make one additional claw attack as part of the same action.

Your body transforms, yet a trace of your humanity remains. Your race becomes {@race scourgeborne|SGttEH}, with a random subrace. Scourgebornes and constructed races, such as manikins, are immune to this effect. If you're already a scourgeborne, the next madness effect applies instead.

Your body transforms into a beast or monstrosity of the GM's choice with CR equal to half your level (rounded up). Apart from this, your transformation follows the rules of the {@spell polymorph} spell, though if you fall to 0 hit points, you fall {@condition unconscious} instead of reverting to your normal form.

table.name: Losing Limbs
rows: You can't hold anything with two hands and you can hold only a single object at a time.
You can't hold anything with two hands and you can hold only a single object at a time.
Your base walking speed is reduced to 5 feet. If you still have at least one leg, you can use a crutch or cane to move at half your original base speed.
Your base walking speed is reduced to 5 feet. If you still have at least one leg, you can use a crutch or cane to move at half your original base speed.
You take an additional 11 ({@damage 2d10}) necrotic damage at the start of each of your turns as you bleed out for 1 minute, or until you receive magical healing.
Time to roll a new character. A creature that loses its head dies if it can't live without it.

table.name: Lovecraftian Horror; Grand Cathedral District
rows: Strange geometries can be spotted in the architecture, hinting at cyclopean influences.
The beast-repelling incense summons rather than repels alien entities from beyond.
The enormous bell tolls 13 times, opening a portal to another dimension.
Eldritch runes are discovered etched into the old stonework, their meaning maddening.
A high priest transforms into an amorphous blob, babbling of sunken cities.

table.name: Lovecraftian Horror; New Bridge District
rows: Bizarre radio signals are picked up by Scion machinery, voices speaking in unknown tongues.
Gravity in an area fluctuates wildly, and floating organs are seen.
Explorers in mines dig too deep and break into a vast underground alien city.
Plantlife becomes covered in strange nodules pulsing with unnatural life.
Scion experiments inadvertently draw the attention of cosmic horrors from beyond.

table.name: Lovecraftian Horror; Outside the Walls
rows: Scholars at the seminary unearth ancient tablets written in unknowable hieroglyphics.
A strange meteor lands beyond the walls, igniting bizarre mutations in nearby plant and animal life.
Researchers discern the cemetery of ash is built over the buried ruins of an alien civilization.
The forest transforms those who wander too deep, body and mind contorting.
Investigations into the Circle of Symbiosis reveal cosmic revelations that break the sanity of members.

table.name: Lovecraftian Horror; Paterna Iter District
rows: The plants in vertical farms form a hive mind, driven to consume human flesh.
Inhuman piping is heard beneath the city streets, impossible flutes playing alien melodies.
Floating spheres of light are seen over the canal, vaporizing those they touch.
A merchant selling strange artifacts causes bizarre transformations in buyers.
A cryptid seen in the sewer transforms those who glimpse it into fish-like beings.

table.name: Lovecraftian Horror; Ruby District
rows: A miner goes mad, convinced the lumps of coal he digs up are fossilized hearts of the dead.
Mysterious symbols and runes are found painted in blood throughout an abandoned warehouse.
Echoing cries are heard from a mine shaft that collapsed years ago, killing all workers inside.
The smog takes on a sinister face and whispers dark secrets to lone wanderers.
A masked plague doctor stalks victims under the cover of the smog, though their murders resemble anything but medical research.

table.name: Lovecraftian Horror; Sanctified District
rows: Nobles begin exhibiting disturbing mutations after consuming a strange new vintage of wine.
Hideous shapes are seen writhing beneath the surface of the ornate ceilings.
The grand colosseum becomes the site of a ritual to an ancient chlorophyll god.
Echoing from the catacombs are sounds no human throat could produce.
An intricate clockwork device found under the castle drives the holder insane.

table.name: Lovecraftian Horror; Shrouded District
rows: Miners go mad after unearthing the fossil of an ancient god-like being.
Demonic cultists perform rituals to awaken a Great Old One buried beneath the city.
A mine shaft breaks into a luminous underworld of fungal growths and strange creatures.
Spatial anomalies fold sections of the district in on itself into impossible geometry.
Residents develop occult powers after exposure to a strange color out of space.

table.name: Lovecraftian Horror; Waterfront District
rows: Heavy rainfall causes bodies to float up in the canals from the remains of a previous Hunt. Some seem not entirely dead...
Strange skittering and screeches are heard from within boarded up buildings.
Severed body parts are found arranged ritualistically near the lightning rods of the Scion's fortress.
Ghostly figures are glimpsed wandering the ruins of buildings destroyed in the First War.
The generators in the Scion's fortress suddenly shutdown, plunging the district into darkness.

entries.name: Tongue Tied
entries: The character becomes mute and cannot speak.

entries.name: Disoriented
entries: The character becomes disoriented and gains disadvantage on Dexterity checks and saving throws.

entries.name: Mental Wounds
entries: The character's mind weakens, and they take an additional 5 ({@damage 1d10}) psychic damage each time they take damage.

entries.name: Mind Warp
entries: The character gains disadvantage on Wisdom saving throws.

entries.name: Foul Stench
entries: The character emits a terrible odor and gains disadvantage on Charisma checks.

entries.name: Hunger
entries: The character feels like they're starving and gains disadvantage on Constitution saving throws.

entries.name: Blurred Vision
entries: The character's vision becomes blurry, gaining disadvantage on attack rolls and {@skill Perception} checks that rely on sight.

entries.name: Frenzy
entries: The character becomes panicked and gains disadvantage on Intelligence and Wisdom saving throws.

entries.name: Weakened
entries: The character gains disadvantage on Strength and Dexterity checks and saving throws.

entries.name: Fatigued
entries: The character gains 1 level of {@condition exhaustion}.

table.name: Noteworthy Locations; Grand Cathedral
rows: Previously a political prison, it later became a hidden experimental chamber for the Obitus Scholare. Now an abandoned space, or so the Church claims.
A grand courtyard filled with expansive gardens, powerful ramparts, and doors that are vigilantly protected during the day and closed tight during the night.

An immense hall that embodies grandeur, complete with awe-inspiring architecture and an ever-present choir singing hymns. It is also notable for the pervasive use of beast incense, particularly at night.
Home to the members of the Radiant Order who diligently protect the city from the Scourge. Its barred windows both protect and confine the hunters.
A vast library of knowledge; everything from accounting documents to forbidden lore can be found there, the most sensitive information hidden in a nightmare realm.
The partially ruined Observatory atop the cathedral, equipped with an extensive celestial tools collection. Once inhabited by the now-missing School of the Eldritch Tongue.
A labyrinth of corridors hosting commercial sites in the Grand Cathedral. The stringent conditions for operating here are offset by unparalleled security and a wealthy customer base.
The symbolic towers representing Strength, Virtue, and Faith. Given a permit, even outsiders can ascend them.

table.name: Noteworthy Locations; Newbridge District
rows: These bare buildings house many of the manikins brought to life during the First War, their dwindling numbers reflected in the decrepit habitat.
This church made entirely of steel serves as a store that offers services ranging from construction to destruction, using the labor of masons and the might of explosive weapons.
Hidden within the Scions' fortress are enclosures meant to house beings constructed by the Scions in their eternal search for power.
Most of the orphans of the city herald from this district, raised by kind souls and interested parties alike.
Atop the Scions' Fortress lies technology capable of partially reverting death.
{@book Ruins of the First War|SGttEH|7|Echoes of History}
Destroyed buildings—testaments to the violence of the First War—that still house artifacts used in the battles. Others beckon unstable minds.
A massive gothic spire that was repurposed by the Scions and now serves as their base of operations.
A miracle of technology, this bridge links the two sides of Luyarnha, though one is more heavily fortified than the other, the infamous Shrouded District inspiring fear.

table.name: Noteworthy Locations; Paterna Iter
rows: Once prosperous but now overrun by toxic vegetation, these greenhouses still shelter some who cultivate illicit herbs and other plants.
An ancient water purification and transportation system now lying in disrepair, long overrun by the Scourge.
This church of the Radiant Faith was turned into a barracks, but is now inaccessible. All previous occupants lay dead, and writhing mold covers its facade.
A decadent noble lives in this sprawling vineyard, hosting parties for the youth of the city. Only manikins are allowed to serve and defend his estate.
Once a bustling hub of transport and commerce, this station now stands desolate and silent, its train tracks repurposed into barricades.
The most ancient weapon shop in Luyarnha. Only the wealthy can afford to purchase the goods and knowledge sold here.
An intricate system of tunnels and sewers sprawls beneath the surface, hosting all sorts of beasts and merchants—namely those who wish to escape the light of justice.
Entire buildings that are transformed into vertical farms are a necessary innovation in desperate times.

table.name: Noteworthy Locations; Ruby District
rows: Enclosing the district's exit points are massive barricades, permanently manned and armed with heavy artillery to prevent any from leaving the area.
A place where the secretive Carmella cultivates parasitic fungus, exotic plants, fragrant flowers, and other natural ingredients for her cures.
Located deep within the Ruby District, this rehabilitated noble mansion stands as a symbol of defiance and resistance against the ruling classes of Luyarnha.
{@book Fortified Radiant Church Buildings|SGttEH|8|Might Makes Right}
Religious sites turned into fortresses, these structures are a testament to the survivors' grit amidst the desperate circumstances.
Once a bustling transportation artery, now a haunting echo of a prosperous past. Strange sounds emanate from its depths, suggesting a possible breach.
These locations are massively overrun by beasts, and no sane individuals dare venture there, apart from treasure-seekers looking to loot corpses.
Beneath the streets lies an intricate sewer system that is a potential habitat of the beasts, home to pioneering strands of Cordyceps Sinensis, and a place of disappearance of illustrious hunters.
{@book Shard of Light's Cathedral|SGttEH|8|Shard of Light}
Amidst the Scourge, this base offers a glimpse of hope, symbolizing the unwavering faith in the light even in the face of bestial adversity.

table.name: Noteworthy Locations; Sanctified District
rows: A hidden shrine to a fallen deity found in the castle's lower depths, rumored to be set within a lake teeming with swirling shadows and disembodied souls. Its existence remains contested.
The hub of the district's economic system, the bank is currently under threat from counterfeit coinage devaluing the city's gold reserves.
The castle room made of unalloyed gold housing Brandt Silverblood's daughter, a girl shrouded in mystery who is rumored to be of incredible beauty.
A place of brutal fights between hunters and beasts, providing entertainment and a display of strength for the populace.
Brothels of questionable repute for nobles who wish to partake in the pleasure of flesh despite the embargo imposed on such practices in the district.
Ancient mansions awarded to the Moongold family, many possessing esoteric relics, from abandoned crypts to otherworldly mirrors that reflect vistas of an unknown reality.
The dwelling of the royal Silverblood family, where they reside and plot, burdened with numerous secrets and tensions.
A secret gathering place for thrill-seeking nobles, where tales of Scourge hunting are shared and strategies developed.

table.name: Noteworthy Locations; Shrouded District
rows: Echoes of a nightmare Realm found in the mines below the city.
{@book Coal Processing Plants & Steam Engines|SGttEH|6|Coal Refineries and Steam Engines}
Industries responsible for refining coal and producing energy, creating the district's pervasive smog in the process.
A narcotics farm and black market for illegal substances.
A heavily guarded arcane vault containing valuable eldritch knowledge.
Vast mines burrowing into valleys neighboring Luyarnha, featuring railways for coal transportation.
{@book Sanctum of the Abyss Watcher|SGttEH|6|Sanctum of the Abyss Watcher}
Secretive temple dedicated to a devouring god, hidden in the shadow of the Grand Cathedral.
A secluded park for narcotic users to experience their highs undisturbed.
A meat processing facility handling unwanted meat from hunted beasts. Formerly manned by manikins.
A small church of the Radiant One offering free healing services in the district. It's perpetually overburdened by the abundance of diseased patients.
The fraction of polluted river beneath the Steelsurge Bridge, connecting the Shrouded District to the Newbridge District.

table.name: Noteworthy Locations; Waterfront District
rows: An imposing prison housing hardened criminals, including spellcasters, casting a dark shadow over the district.
A lively tavern popular among dock workers and navigators known for its strong grog.
These once-thriving shipbuilding industries now stand desolate and underworked due to the lockdown.
{@book Ossuary of the Drowned|SGttEH|10|The Gilded Harbor}
An underwater graveyard, containing the remains of those claimed by the Moryanne and the cannons of Luyarnha.

An absolutely massive ship built for the Radiant Church, whose construction ended a few months ago. It was meant to leave on long-term missions to spread the gospel of the Radiant Faith to the four corners of the world, but never left the docks due to the lockdown.
Hidden locations within the Abyssal Keep from where illegal items and desperate people are covertly transported within the city to get access to the miracle cures within.
Mysterious underwater churches dedicated to the abyssal god of the Deep Ones; it is often a one-way trip for outsiders of their ranks.
A massive lighthouse that has been disaffected. Howls can be heard coming from it on some nights.

table.name: Oath of the Eldritch Hunt Spells
rows: {@spell Evard's Black Tentacles|PHB|black tentacles}, {@spell maiden of bones|SGttEH}{@font |radiantcross}

table.name: Random Chaos Events
rows: The characters hear ghostly whispering from the darkness from a group of {@dice 1d4+1} {@creature geist|SGttEH|geists} of victims killed in the cavern. The geists are hostile and will attack the party if they are not placated with a successful {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check.

Geometric patterns and shapes seem to ebb and flow in silvery lines across the surface of the walls. Creatures feel drawn to them, and attempts to read them must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or gain a {@table short-term madness|SGttEH} effect {@homebrew |(see the "Steinhardt's Madness System" chapter in Steinhardt's Guide to the Eldritch Hunt)}. The patterns disappear after 1 minute.

The characters see {@dice 1d4+1} {@creature gargoyle} statues etched into niches in the room's upper walls. The statues are hostile and attack the party, but a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check reveals that they can be instantly deactivated by reciting an ancient prayer inscribed on one of the statues.

The sound of a child weeping can be heard from the next room. The sound continues to come from a distance, no matter which direction the characters move. The sound lasts 30 minutes before it ends with a choked-off scream of terror.

The cave floor gives way beneath a random character, and they must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or fall 20 feet down into a pit filled with {@dice 1d4+1} {@creature giant centipede|MM|giant centipedes}. The {@creature giant centipede|MM|centipedes} are hostile and attack the party.

A wave of eldritch energy washes over the party, and each character must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the character's mouth begins to melt and flow into a solid piece of smooth flesh (or metal), and they cannot speak. This effect lasts for 10 minutes or until removed by a '{@spell remove curse}' spell or similar effect.

table.name: Random Encounters
rows: The {@creature Veiled Hunter|SGttEH} {@homebrew |(page 380)} uses his Rootprison ability to ambush the party, without revealing himself, before fleeing. A {@creature skulking shade|SGttEH} {@homebrew |(page 337)} then attacks.
A {@creature revenant bear|SGttEH} {@homebrew |(page 323)} roars out of the misty forest, straight for the party.

The mist grows thick, and shadows of horrific monstrosities are seen walking just out of reach around the party. The party loses an hour of travel, and each creature must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or gain a {@table short-term madness|SGttEH} effect {@homebrew |(see "Steinhardt's Madness System," page 269)}.
Four {@creature screechwing|SGttEH|screechwings} {@homebrew |(page 321)} fly from out of the tree tops and attack the party. They each flee when reduced to fifty percent of their total hit points.

Three {@creature corrupted dryad|SGttEH|corrupted dryads} step from the trees and scream their rage at the party, attacking them on sight. They are covered in open sores, lesions, and leaking pustules, as if diseased. They are immune to acid damage, and their melee weapon attacks deal an additional 3 ({@damage 1d6}) necrotic damage.

The hour passes without physical assault, but each character must succeed on a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw or suffer visions of melted corpses lining the path and hanging from tree branches. A failure results in gaining 1 point of {@condition exhaustion}. Attempts to touch the remains result in them dissolving into smoke or exploding into a swarm of buzzing insects that dissipate into the forest.

entries.name: {@disease Slimy Doom|PHB}

entries.name: {@disease Sight Rot|DMG}
entries: The character gains disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight and suffers disadvantage on ranged attacks from blurred vision for the next 24 hours.

table.name: Short-Term Madness
rows: Your mind is liberated from any sense of self you may possess.
Without an ego, you are immune to the {@condition charmed} condition.
You mimic the mannerisms, behaviour, and speech patterns of the creature closest to you when you gained this madness.
Desperate to find yourself again and believing anything, you automatically fail saving throws against being {@condition charmed}.
Your mind is invaded by the sound of the cosmos.
Painful sounds pale in comparison to the cacophony in your head; you are immune to thunder damage.
Eldritch utterings scratch your brain; you hear the soft caress of whispers behind your back.
The sound of the cosmos drowns out all other noise, closing you to the world. You are {@condition deafened} and have disadvantage on saving throws made to maintain your {@status concentration}.
You have seen too much; your mind can't understand it, causing your sight to become erratic and unreliable.
Your vision expands as if you are under the effect of the {@spell see invisibility} spell.
Spectral forms flitter at the corners of your eyes, vanishing when you turn your head.
You are {@condition blinded}, and you can't use any special senses you use to see, such as {@sense blindsight} or {@sense tremorsense|MM}.
The madness inside you bursts forth as haunting screams.

Your scream is so loud that it can cause damage. As a bonus action on each of your turns, you can scream at a creature you see within 30 feet of you. If the target can hear you, it must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 1d12} thunder damage on a failure or half as much damage on a success.
You can't talk properly; yelling is the only way you can communicate.
Your screams are so overwhelming that any creature within 300 feet of you can hear you talk. You also can't form coherent sentences or utter the vocal components of spells.
Your posture crumples, as you try to make sense of the insanity before you.

You become incredibly skittish. When you are the target of an attack or an effect that requires you to make a Dexterity saving throw, you can use your reaction to begin moving evasively, gaining a +1 bonus to AC and advantage on Dexterity saving throws until the start of your next turn.
You desperately look for a parental figure that can protect you. Once you find such a person, you latch on to them and refuse to leave their side, no matter what.
You fall {@condition prone} and can't stand, as your legs refuse to obey you, and you can't use any flying speed you possess.
You realize that your hands are blasphemous tools.
These tools can break the minds of your foes. Once per turn when you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can deal an extra {@damage 1d8} psychic damage to it.
You refuse to use your hands for anything, keeping them hidden from view. If someone stares at them, it makes you extremely uncomfortable and defensive.
You shouldn't touch anything. You drop anything you are holding, and can't hold items or {@action grapple} creatures.
Your body breaks down under the insanity.
You are immune to the {@condition poisoned} condition.
You start emitting a foul smell that is unpleasant even to you, and no amount of washing or magic can remove it.
You are {@condition poisoned}, even if you are immune to the condition.
The Eldritch Horrors are revealed to you, bathing you in fear.

When you gain this madness, each creature within 30 feet of you must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} of you for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
You become paranoid and fearful of any movement or sound.

You become {@condition frightened} of your allies. You must take the {@action Dash} action and move away from them by the quickest available route on each of your turns, unless there is nowhere to move. If you start your turn in a location where you can't see any of your allies, you can use your action to end the madness.

You realize your mind has been holding back your body, and you can now act freely. You have an additional action on each of your turns. That action can be used only to take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, {@action Hide}, or {@action Use an Object} action.
You burst into spontaneous fits of laughter randomly, even at the most inappropriate times.
You are {@condition incapacitated}. This effect ends early if you take damage equal to twice your level or if a {@spell greater restoration} spell is cast on you.
The revelations from beyond afflict you.
Your body ignores all pain; only the Eldritch Truth matters. You are immune to the {@condition stunned} condition.
You speak to others of the Eldritch Truth in a way that seems limpid to you, but is perhaps not so clear to others. Your sentences are cryptic for the un-ascended mind.
You are {@condition stunned}. This effect ends early if you take damage equal to your level or if a {@spell greater restoration} spell is cast on you.
The beast within you awakens and attempts to take control.

Your body releases its animalistic instincts, without the influence of your mind to restrain it. You are under the effect of the {@spell haste} spell, although it doesn't require {@status concentration}. The spell ends when the madness does.
Your speech is slurred, as if you're intoxicated, and you punctuate your sentences with animal noises.

You fall {@condition unconscious}, your mind fighting its hardest to not let you become a beast. This effect ends early if you take damage equal to your level or if a {@spell greater restoration} spell is cast on you.

table.name: Shrouded District Diseases
intro: The Shrouded District is rife with various diseases. The following is a non-exhaustive list of illnesses that can be contracted within the district. A creature exposed for a prolonged duration to an environment or another creature hosting one of these diseases must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or contract it. Each affliction lasts for {@dice 3d4} days or until cured by a {@spell lesser restoration} spell or similar magic.
rows: This disease sets the lungs ablaze, with the creature writhing in agony as inflammation burns its respiratory system. The creature takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage every {@dice 1d4} hours.

This affliction breaks the blood vessels of the eyes, clouding perception, as if viewing the world through a veil of blood. The creature gains disadvantage on {@skill Perception} checks that rely on sight and suffers disadvantage on ranged attack rolls from blurred vision.

A creeping rot spreads through the creature's lungs, its breaths growing ever more shallow and ragged as its body fights to draw in air. The creature's speed is reduced by 10 feet, and it has disadvantage on Dexterity checks and Dexterity saving throws.

This is a carnal disease that causes the victim's organs to slowly turn into nonfunctional fibrotic tissue, starting from the gut and spreading outward. A creature affected by this disease must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw every 24 hours. If it fails three of these saving throws before the disease ends, the creature dies of multiple organ failure.

The creature's muscles waste away under the relentless onslaught of this disease, sapping its strength and vitality. The creature must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw every hour, having its hit point maximum reduced by {@dice 1d4} on each failure.

This is a vile disease that spreads through filth and squalor, leaving the creature wracked with fever and trembling with weakness. The creature's speed is halved, and it gains disadvantage on all attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

The creature is struck down by a dread disease that fills its veins and lungs with necrotic rot; this infection is prevalent amongst miners. The creature gains disadvantage on Constitution checks and Constitution saving throws, and must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw every 24 hours, taking 5 ({@damage 1d10}) necrotic damage on a failure.

The symptoms begin as a queasy feeling and painful stomach cramps before devolving into more severe colics. The creature suffers a −1 penalty to ability checks and attack rolls. This penalty increases by 1 every 24 hours. If the penalty reaches −8, the creature dies.

condition.name: Fear
entries: Gothic horror evokes constant feelings of dread and foreboding. As Game Master, you can reinforce this by requiring periodic saves against the {@condition frightened} condition whenever characters encounter terrifying sights or enemies.
The {@condition frightened} condition is all fun and games, but what if you could intensify it? Consider this optional rule to add some more tension to your games.

When a character succeeds or fails on a saving throw against an effect that causes or ends the {@condition frightened} condition, instead of gaining or ending the {@condition frightened} condition, they gain or lose 1 fear level. This fear level ranges from 0 to 4, and each level is cumulative with the previous one.

items.name: Fear Level 0:
entries: No effect

items.name: Fear Level 1:
entries: {@condition Frightened}

items.name: Fear Level 2:
entries: Speed halved

items.name: Fear Level 3:
entries: Disadvantage on all attack rolls and saving throws

items.name: Fear Level 4:
entries: Absolute terror—the character becomes {@condition incapacitated}

Characters with a fear level of 1 or more can make a fear save at the end of each of their turns, reducing their fear level by 1 on a successful save. Certain spells and class abilities may also allow a character to reduce their fear level.
